Data.event_text: 4 January  Severe weather hits Coromandel and the upper North Island bringing thunderstorms and torrential rain. Holidaymakers are forced to evacuate and continuing severe weather causes numerous landslips.

links.text: -"Coromandel in for further deluges, severe thunderstorm warnings for South Island". Radio New Zealand. 6 January 2023. Archived from the original on 6 January 2023. Retrieved 7 January 2023.-
-"Coromandel in for further deluges, severe thunderstorm warnings for South Island". Radio New Zealand. 6 January 2023. Archived from the original on 6 January 2023. Retrieved 7 January 2023.-

Data.event_text: 9 January  COVID-19 in New Zealand The "Kraken" subvariant of Omicron is detected in New Zealand for the first time after genome sequencing of two cases. Health officials are confident the current COVID-19 response is appropriate.

links.text: -"Covid-19: XBB.1.5 variant detected in New Zealand". Radio New Zealand. 9 January 2023. Archived from the original on 12 January 2023. Retrieved 13 January 2023.-
-"Covid-19: XBB.1.5 variant detected in New Zealand". Radio New Zealand. 9 January 2023. Archived from the original on 12 January 2023. Retrieved 13 January 2023.-

Data.event_text: 10 January  Cyclone Hale impacts the North Island, causing flooding and slips in Coromandel and Gisborne.
18 January  A Qantas flight travelling from Auckland to Sydney lands safely after issuing a mayday call.

links.text: -"Qantas flight from Auckland issues mayday call". RNZ. 18 January 2023. Archived from the original on 20 January 2023. Retrieved 20 January 2023.-
-"Qantas flight from Auckland issues mayday call". RNZ. 18 January 2023. Archived from the original on 20 January 2023. Retrieved 20 January 2023.-

Data.event_text: Jacinda Ardern announces her pending resignation as prime minister and Labour Party leader.
A wild kiwi egg is laid in Wellington for the first time in more than 100 years.

links.text: -"First wild kiwi egg laid in Wellington in over a century". RNZ. 19 January 2023. Archived from the original on 20 January 2023. Retrieved 20 January 2023.-
-"First wild kiwi egg laid in Wellington in over a century". RNZ. 19 January 2023. Archived from the original on 20 January 2023. Retrieved 20 January 2023.-

Data.event_text: 22 January  Chris Hipkins is unanimously elected leader of the Labour Party.

links.text: -"Live: Chris Hipkins to become New Zealand's 41st prime minister". RNZ News. 22 January 2023. Archived from the original on 23 September 2023. Retrieved 22 January 2023.-
-"Live: Chris Hipkins to become New Zealand's 41st prime minister". RNZ News. 22 January 2023. Archived from the original on 23 September 2023. Retrieved 22 January 2023.-

Data.event_text: 25 January  Chris Hipkins and Carmel Sepuloni are sworn in as Prime Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, respectively, at Government House, Wellington.

links.text: -"Appointment ceremony of the new prime minister and deputy prime minister". The Governor-General of New Zealand. Government House. 25 January 2023. Archived from the original on 24 January 2023. Retrieved 25 January 2023.-

-"Appointment ceremony of the new prime minister and deputy prime minister". The Governor-General of New Zealand. Government House. 25 January 2023. Archived from the original on 24 January 2023. Retrieved 25 January 2023.-

Data.event_text: 27 January  Torrential rain in Auckland causes widespread flooding, slips, evacuations, and the deaths of four people (from Cyclone Hale).

links.text: -"NZ weather: Evacuations as Auckland hit by major flooding, fire crews responding to over 400 emergency calls". Newshub. 27 January 2023. Archived from the original on 26 January 2023. Retrieved 27 January 2023.-

-"NZ weather: Evacuations as Auckland hit by major flooding, fire crews responding to over 400 emergency calls". Newshub. 27 January 2023. Archived from the original on 26 January 2023. Retrieved 27 January 2023.-
-"Auckland floods: Death toll now 3 after landslide brings down Remuera house". Stuff. 28 January 2023. Archived from the original on 28 January 2023. Retrieved 28 January 2023.-
-"Auckland floods: Death toll now 3 after landslide brings down Remuera house". Stuff. 28 January 2023. Archived from the original on 28 January 2023. Retrieved 28 January 2023.-
-"Police confirm fourth person found dead after being swept away by floodwaters". RNZ. 29 January 2023. Archived from the original on 29 January 2023. Retrieved 29 January 2023.-
-"Police confirm fourth person found dead after being swept away by floodwaters". RNZ. 29 January 2023. Archived from the original on 29 January 2023. Retrieved 29 January 2023.-

Data.event_text: 28 January  The Interislander ferry MV Kaitaki loses power in heavy seas and drifts near rocks off Sinclair Head on Wellington's south coast.

links.text: -"KiwiRail charged after Kaitaki Cook Strait breakdown". 1News. Retrieved 18 January 2024.-

Data.event_text: 1 February  A second wave of severe weather and torrential rain hits Auckland, worsening the already catastrophic flooding.

links.text: -"Live: Northland declares state of emergency; severe weather warnings in place; over 100 homes red-stickered". New Zealand Herald. Archived from the original on 30 January 2023. Retrieved 31 January 2023.-

-"Live: Northland declares state of emergency; severe weather warnings in place; over 100 homes red-stickered". New Zealand Herald. Archived from the original on 30 January 2023. Retrieved 31 January 2023.-

Data.event_text: 5 February  Auckland begins a series of significant large-scale clean up operations in the aftermath of catastrophic flooding. Authorities believe the city is now out of danger.

links.text: -"Auckland 'nearly' out of the woods after floods – MetService". 1News. Archived from the original on 5 February 2023. Retrieved 5 February 2023.-
-"Auckland 'nearly' out of the woods after floods – MetService". 1News. Archived from the original on 5 February 2023. Retrieved 5 February 2023.-
-"Auckland floods clean-up: Volunteers gather to help out". Radio New Zealand. Archived from the original on 4 February 2023. Retrieved 5 February 2023.-
-"Auckland floods clean-up: Volunteers gather to help out". Radio New Zealand. Archived from the original on 4 February 2023. Retrieved 5 February 2023.-

Data.event_text: 8 February  Police Commissioner Andrew Coster announced the seizure of 3.2 tonnes of cocaine floating in the Pacific that was probably destined for Australia, an amount that represents 30 years of consumption in New Zealand.

links.text: -Dunseath, Finlay (8 February 2023). "Police snare massive cocaine haul floating in the ocean". Stuff. Archived from the original on 8 February 2023. Retrieved 9 February 2023.-
-Dunseath, Finlay (8 February 2023). "Police snare massive cocaine haul floating in the ocean". Stuff. Archived from the original on 8 February 2023. Retrieved 9 February 2023.-

Data.event_text: 12 February  Cyclone Gabrielle Thousands of people are left without power as Cyclone Gabrielle makes landfall over the North Island. The regions of Northland and Auckland are put under a state of emergency.

links.text: -"Cyclone Gabrielle: Thousands left without power in New Zealand". BBC News. 12 February 2023. Archived from the original on 13 February 2023. Retrieved 13 February 2023.-
-"Cyclone Gabrielle: Thousands left without power in New Zealand". BBC News. 12 February 2023. Archived from the original on 13 February 2023. Retrieved 13 February 2023.-

Data.event_text: Cyclone Gabrielle A national state of emergency is declared as Cyclone Gabrielle continues to impact the North Island bringing extreme weather, flooding and land slides. A national state of emergency will allow the Government to step in and handle the emergency response.

links.text: -"National state of emergency declared". 1News. 14 February 2023. Archived from the original on 13 February 2023. Retrieved 14 February 2023.-
-"National state of emergency declared". 1News. 14 February 2023. Archived from the original on 13 February 2023. Retrieved 14 February 2023.-

Data.event_text: The ngaro huruhuru (native bee) is named the inaugural New Zealand Bug of the Year.

links.text: -"New Zealand bug of the year 2023". Archived from the original on 14 February 2023. Retrieved 14 February 2023.-
-"New Zealand bug of the year 2023". Archived from the original on 14 February 2023. Retrieved 14 February 2023.-

Data.event_text: Cyclone Gabrielle Anne, Princess Royal and Vice Admiral Sir Timothy Laurence arrive in Wellington for their tour of New Zealand. The pair's planned military duties in Palmerston North were postponed. Instead, they travelled to the National Crisis Management Centre at the Beehive to meet with staff from agencies involved in the cyclone response. They also conducted the Service of Remembrance at the National War Memorial and paid respects at the United Kingdom memorial.[needs update]

links.text: -Waiwiri-Smith, Lyric (14 February 2023). "Princess Anne landing in Wellington, changing plans due to Cyclone Gabrielle". Stuff. Archived from the original on 15 February 2023. Retrieved 15 February 2023.-

-Waiwiri-Smith, Lyric (14 February 2023). "Princess Anne landing in Wellington, changing plans due to Cyclone Gabrielle". Stuff. Archived from the original on 15 February 2023. Retrieved 15 February 2023.-

Data.event_text: A magnitude 6.0 earthquake hits the lower North Island, 50 kilometres (31 mi) north-west of Paraparaumu at a depth of 54 km. Shaking was felt nationwide and it caused cracks to form in the town's fire station.

links.text: -"Magnitude 6.0, Wed Feb 15 2023 7:38 PM". GeoNet. Archived from the original on 15 February 2023. Retrieved 10 March 2025.-
-"Magnitude 6.0, Wed Feb 15 2023 7:38 PM". GeoNet. Archived from the original on 15 February 2023. Retrieved 10 March 2025.-
-"Lower North Island rocked by magnitude 6.1 earthquake". Stuff. 15 February 2023. Archived from the original on 15 February 2023. Retrieved 15 February 2023.-
-"Lower North Island rocked by magnitude 6.1 earthquake". Stuff. 15 February 2023. Archived from the original on 15 February 2023. Retrieved 15 February 2023.-
-"Paraparaumu Fire Station continues to operate as investigation continues". Kapiti News. The New Zealand Herald. Retrieved 10 March 2025.-

Data.event_text: 16 February  Cyclone Gabrielle New Zealand starts accepting offers of international assistance.[citation needed]
1 March  Protesters disrupt a Drag Queen Story Hour event at the Avondale Library in Auckland, forcing its closure.

links.text: -"Auckland library closes after drag Storytime protest". 1News. TVNZ. 1 March 2023. Archived from the original on 3 April 2023. Retrieved 26 March 2024.-
-"Auckland library closes after drag Storytime protest". 1News. TVNZ. 1 March 2023. Archived from the original on 3 April 2023. Retrieved 26 March 2024.-

Data.event_text: Large climate protests take place across the country as thousands march to demand immediate climate action from the government. The protesters make a number of demands and briefly stage a "sit in" at the Christchurch City Council.

links.text: -"Climate strikes: Thousands march around New Zealand to demand action from government". Radio New Zealand. 3 March 2023. Archived from the original on 26 May 2023. Retrieved 3 March 2023.-
-"Climate strikes: Thousands march around New Zealand to demand action from government". Radio New Zealand. 3 March 2023. Archived from the original on 26 May 2023. Retrieved 3 March 2023.-

-Sharma, Akula; Franks, Raphael (3 March 2023). "Thousands of climate activists march nationwide, demand urgent action by NZ's leaders". The New Zealand Herald. Archived from the original on 3 April 2023. Retrieved 3 June 2023.-

-Sharma, Akula; Franks, Raphael (3 March 2023). "Thousands of climate activists march nationwide, demand urgent action by NZ's leaders". The New Zealand Herald. Archived from the original on 3 April 2023. Retrieved 3 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Christchurch Schools Rebuild programme, which is rebuilding and repairing 115 earthquake-damaged schools in greater Christchurch, is given $301 million. This increases the total investment in it to $1.6 billion.

links.text: -"Govt announces $301 million for Chch schools damaged by earthquakes". 1News. 3 March 2023. Retrieved 7 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: 7 March  The 2023 census takes place.

links.text: -"2023 Census announced | Stats NZ". www.stats.govt.nz. Archived from the original on 20 January 2023. Retrieved 20 January 2023.-
-"2023 Census announced | Stats NZ". www.stats.govt.nz. Archived from the original on 20 January 2023. Retrieved 20 January 2023.-

Data.event_text: 14 March  Protesters picket the "Queens Telling Stories" event at Christchurch's Turangi Library.

links.text: -Burns, Adam (14 March 2024). "Protests at drag queen storytime event sparked more support, organiser says". Radio New Zealand. Retrieved 1 April 2024.-

Data.event_text: 15 March  Stuart Nash resigned as Minister of Police following revelations he asked the Police Commissioner Andrew Coster to appeal a decision he felt was too light, a breach of the expectation that the Government remains neutral in regards to operational Police matters.

links.text: -"Stuart Nash has resigned as police minister, PM Hipkins says". RNZ. 15 March 2023. Archived from the original on 29 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-
-"Stuart Nash has resigned as police minister, PM Hipkins says". RNZ. 15 March 2023. Archived from the original on 29 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-

Data.event_text: New Zealand enacts a ban of TikTok on devices connected to parliament citing cybersecurity concerns.

links.text: -"New Zealand to ban TikTok on devices linked to parliament, cites security concerns". Reuters. 16 March 2023. Archived from the original on 17 March 2023. Retrieved 17 March 2023.-
-"New Zealand to ban TikTok on devices linked to parliament, cites security concerns". Reuters. 16 March 2023. Archived from the original on 17 March 2023. Retrieved 17 March 2023.-

Data.event_text: Early childhood, primary, and secondary school teachers affiliated with the New Zealand Educational Institute (NZEI) and Post Primary Teachers' Association (PPTA) hold a nationwide strike following the breakdown of negotiations with the Government over salaries and work conditions.

links.text: -"Primary teachers join nationwide strike next week". 1News. TVNZ. 9 March 2023. Archived from the original on 15 March 2023. Retrieved 30 March 2023.-
-"Primary teachers join nationwide strike next week". 1News. TVNZ. 9 March 2023. Archived from the original on 15 March 2023. Retrieved 30 March 2023.-
-"In pictures: Teachers strike". Radio New Zealand. 16 March 2023. Archived from the original on 28 March 2023. Retrieved 30 March 2023.-
-"In pictures: Teachers strike". Radio New Zealand. 16 March 2023. Archived from the original on 28 March 2023. Retrieved 30 March 2023.-
-McCulloch, Gabrielle (15 March 2023). "Why kindergarten teachers are joining the nationwide strike". Stuff. Archived from the original on 22 April 2023. Retrieved 24 May 2023.-
-McCulloch, Gabrielle (15 March 2023). "Why kindergarten teachers are joining the nationwide strike". Stuff. Archived from the original on 22 April 2023. Retrieved 24 May 2023.-

Data.event_text: 17 March  Nash subsequently admitted to a third incident of misconduct where he contacted the Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment (MBIE) to advocate for a migrant health professional in Napier in September 2022.

links.text: -"Stuart Nash demoted to bottom of Cabinet, now on his 'final warning' – Hipkins". RNZ. 17 March 2023. Archived from the original on 28 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-
-"Stuart Nash demoted to bottom of Cabinet, now on his 'final warning' – Hipkins". RNZ. 17 March 2023. Archived from the original on 28 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-

Data.event_text: A rally organised by Posie Parker in central Auckland ends in chaos after counter-protesters, estimated to number in the thousands, make too much noise for her to speak. Parker later left by police escort.

links.text: -"Posie Parker rally: Hundreds counter protest at Albert Park". RNZ. 25 March 2023. Archived from the original on 25 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-
-"Posie Parker rally: Hundreds counter protest at Albert Park". RNZ. 25 March 2023. Archived from the original on 25 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-

Data.event_text: Marama Davidson, Green Party co-leader is hit by a motorcyclist and injured. On the same day, she made controversial comments about white cisgender men committing violence.

links.text: -"Marama Davidson hit by motorcyclist after Posie Parker protest". RNZ. 25 March 2023. Archived from the original on 29 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-
-"Marama Davidson hit by motorcyclist after Posie Parker protest". RNZ. 25 March 2023. Archived from the original on 29 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-
-"National Party leader Christopher Luxon demands Marama Davidson apologise to cis white men". RNZ. 28 March 2023. Archived from the original on 29 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-
-"National Party leader Christopher Luxon demands Marama Davidson apologise to cis white men". RNZ. 28 March 2023. Archived from the original on 29 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-

Data.event_text: Kea are spotted in Christchurch's Port Hills for the first time in many years.

links.text: -"Appeal for more sightings after two kea spotted in Christchurch's Port Hills". RNZ. 25 March 2023. Archived from the original on 29 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-
-"Appeal for more sightings after two kea spotted in Christchurch's Port Hills". RNZ. 25 March 2023. Archived from the original on 29 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-

Data.event_text: 28 March  A forth incident involving Nash reveals that in 2020, he emailed two of his donors, who were commercial property owners, about a commercial rent relief policy Cabinet was discussing. Nash is stripped of all his remaining ministerial portfolios.

links.text: -"Fresh revelation of Cabinet rule breach leads to Stuart Nash's sacking". RNZ. 28 March 2023. Archived from the original on 28 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-
-"Fresh revelation of Cabinet rule breach leads to Stuart Nash's sacking". RNZ. 28 March 2023. Archived from the original on 28 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-

Data.event_text: Prime Minister Chris Hipkins announces a review into Stuart Nash's communications with his two donors.

links.text: -"Prime Minister Chris Hipkins announces review into Stuart Nash's communications with donors". Radio New Zealand. 29 March 2023. Archived from the original on 29 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-

-"Prime Minister Chris Hipkins announces review into Stuart Nash's communications with donors". Radio New Zealand. 29 March 2023. Archived from the original on 29 March 2023. Retrieved 29 March 2023.-

Data.event_text: Secondary school teachers stage a second national strike following the breakdown of negotiations with the Government.

links.text: -Kenny, Lee; Sommerville, Troels; Schwanecke, Gianina (29 March 2023). "Schools shut as secondary teachers continue after negotiations impasse". Stuff. Archived from the original on 29 March 2023. Retrieved 30 March 2023.-

-Kenny, Lee; Sommerville, Troels; Schwanecke, Gianina (29 March 2023). "Schools shut as secondary teachers continue after negotiations impasse". Stuff. Archived from the original on 29 March 2023. Retrieved 30 March 2023.-
-"Secondary school teachers striking again around the country". Radio New Zealand. 29 March 2023. Archived from the original on 29 March 2023. Retrieved 30 March 2023.-
-"Secondary school teachers striking again around the country". Radio New Zealand. 29 March 2023. Archived from the original on 29 March 2023. Retrieved 30 March 2023.-

Data.event_text: 30 March  New Zealand records its first case of rabies in a human. A patient who had been in hospital since early March died from the disease, which did not spread further.

links.text: -"New Zealand reveals first-ever rabies death". News24. Archived from the original on 6 April 2023. Retrieved 7 April 2023.-
-"New Zealand reveals first-ever rabies death". News24. Archived from the original on 6 April 2023. Retrieved 7 April 2023.-

Data.event_text: 10 April  A tornado sweeps through the Tasman Region damaging fifty properties. It tears the roofs off at least twelve houses, brings down trees and powerlines and leaves one person trapped in their car.

links.text: -"Tornado sweeps through upper South Island as Aucklanders clean up from another tornado". Radio New Zealand. 10 April 2023. Archived from the original on 10 April 2023. Retrieved 10 April 2023.-
-"Tornado sweeps through upper South Island as Aucklanders clean up from another tornado". Radio New Zealand. 10 April 2023. Archived from the original on 10 April 2023. Retrieved 10 April 2023.-

-"Wild weather: 50 homes damaged after 'unreal' tornado strikes near Nelson; 'vigorous thunderstorms', 10mm hail trigger flooding on Kāpiti Coast". New Zealand Herald. Archived from the original on 10 April 2023. Retrieved 10 April 2023.-

-"Wild weather: 50 homes damaged after 'unreal' tornado strikes near Nelson; 'vigorous thunderstorms', 10mm hail trigger flooding on Kāpiti Coast". New Zealand Herald. Archived from the original on 10 April 2023. Retrieved 10 April 2023.-

Data.event_text: 11 April  Prime Minister Hipkins and Minister of Health Ayesha Verrall confirm that the New Zealand Government would retain some COVID-19 restrictions such as the seven-day mandatory isolation period for positive cases and mask wearing requirements at health facilities.

links.text: -"Covid-19 restrictions: Cabinet to keep self-isolating mandatory for at least two months". Radio New Zealand. 11 April 2023. Archived from the original on 30 April 2023. Retrieved 11 April 2023.-
-"Covid-19 restrictions: Cabinet to keep self-isolating mandatory for at least two months". Radio New Zealand. 11 April 2023. Archived from the original on 30 April 2023. Retrieved 11 April 2023.-

Data.event_text: The New Zealand Government overhauls its Three Waters water infrastructure reform programme, renaming it the Water Services Reform Programme.

links.text: -"Major shakeup will see affordable water reforms led and delivered locally". Beehive.govt.nz. New Zealand Government. 13 April 2023. Archived from the original on 13 April 2023. Retrieved 19 April 2023.-

-"Major shakeup will see affordable water reforms led and delivered locally". Beehive.govt.nz. New Zealand Government. 13 April 2023. Archived from the original on 13 April 2023. Retrieved 19 April 2023.-
-"Three Waters reset: Mega-entities scrapped as new model proposed". 1News. TVNZ. 13 April 2023. Archived from the original on 13 April 2023. Retrieved 19 April 2023.-
-"Three Waters reset: Mega-entities scrapped as new model proposed". 1News. TVNZ. 13 April 2023. Archived from the original on 13 April 2023. Retrieved 19 April 2023.-

Data.event_text: 29 April  The Dominion Post is revamped as The Post. On 27 , Stuff confirmed that The Dominion Post would adopt its new name The Post on 29 April. Stuff also announced that it would launch a new subscription-based website for The Post that would co-exist with the free Stuff news website.

links.text: -"Stuff to put up first paywalls for news". Radio New Zealand. 27 April 2023. Archived from the original on 27 April 2023. Retrieved 28 April 2023.-
-"Stuff to put up first paywalls for news". Radio New Zealand. 27 April 2023. Archived from the original on 27 April 2023. Retrieved 28 April 2023.-

Data.event_text: 3 May  Meka Whaitiri resigns from the Labour Party and loses her ministerial portfolios, but remains in Parliament as an independent MP sitting with Te Pāti Māori.

links.text: -McConnell, Glenn (3 May 2023). "Meka Whaitiri quits as a Labour minister, confirms defection to Māori Party". Stuff. Archived from the original on 12 May 2023. Retrieved 12 May 2023.-
-McConnell, Glenn (3 May 2023). "Meka Whaitiri quits as a Labour minister, confirms defection to Māori Party". Stuff. Archived from the original on 12 May 2023. Retrieved 12 May 2023.-

-Franks, Raphael; Tapaleao, Vaimoana; Neilson, Michael (10 May 2023). "Former Labour Minister Meka Whaitiri interviewed for first time since shock defection to Te Pāti Māori". The New Zealand Herald. Archived from the original on 12 May 2023. Retrieved 12 May 2023.-

-Franks, Raphael; Tapaleao, Vaimoana; Neilson, Michael (10 May 2023). "Former Labour Minister Meka Whaitiri interviewed for first time since shock defection to Te Pāti Māori". The New Zealand Herald. Archived from the original on 12 May 2023. Retrieved 12 May 2023.-

Data.event_text: 4 May  Secondary school teachers affiliated with the Post Primary Teachers' Association (PPTA) launch a series of nationwide rolling strikes throughout the month of May in response to a pay dispute with the Ministry of Education.

links.text: -McCulloch, Gabrielle (2 May 2023). "Teacher strikes: What you need to know about the upcoming protests". Stuff. Archived from the original on 21 May 2023. Retrieved 24 May 2023.-
-McCulloch, Gabrielle (2 May 2023). "Teacher strikes: What you need to know about the upcoming protests". Stuff. Archived from the original on 21 May 2023. Retrieved 24 May 2023.-
-"Teachers rolling strike action begins today: What you need to know". The New Zealand Herald. NZME. 2 May 2023. Archived from the original on 18 May 2023. Retrieved 24 May 2023.-
-"Teachers rolling strike action begins today: What you need to know". The New Zealand Herald. NZME. 2 May 2023. Archived from the original on 18 May 2023. Retrieved 24 May 2023.-

Data.event_text: Heavy rain hits the lower North Island and the upper South Island bringing surface flooding and landslips. Evacuations take place in Tasman District after a river bursts its banks and several other regions issue weather warnings.

links.text: -"Evacuations as heavy rain warnings continue into Saturday". Radio New Zealand. 5 May 2023. Archived from the original on 5 May 2023. Retrieved 6 May 2023.-
-"Evacuations as heavy rain warnings continue into Saturday". Radio New Zealand. 5 May 2023. Archived from the original on 5 May 2023. Retrieved 6 May 2023.-

Data.event_text: Elizabeth Kerekere resigns from the Green Party, but remains in Parliament as an independent MP.

links.text: -Dexter, Giles (10 May 2023). "Elizabeth Kerekere rules out joining Te Pāti Māori". RNZ News. Archived from the original on 12 May 2023. Retrieved 12 May 2023.-
-Dexter, Giles (10 May 2023). "Elizabeth Kerekere rules out joining Te Pāti Māori". RNZ News. Archived from the original on 12 May 2023. Retrieved 12 May 2023.-

Data.event_text: 6 May  The coronation of Charles III takes place in London.

links.text: -Kirka, Danica; Lawless, Jill (7 May 2023). "Charles III crowned in ancient rite at Westminster Abbey". Stuff. Archived from the original on 7 May 2023. Retrieved 7 May 2023.-
-Kirka, Danica; Lawless, Jill (7 May 2023). "Charles III crowned in ancient rite at Westminster Abbey". Stuff. Archived from the original on 7 May 2023. Retrieved 7 May 2023.-

Data.event_text: 12 May  Early childhood education teachers affiliated with the New Zealand Educational Institute (NZEI) accept a pay offer from the Ministry of Education, which also increases sick leave by 15 days. Their primary school colleagues have voted to hold out on the Ministry's pay offer.

links.text: -McCulloch, Gabrielle (12 May 2023). "Kindy teachers accept latest pay offer, while primary teachers hold out for more". Stuff. Archived from the original on 12 May 2023. Retrieved 24 May 2023.-
-McCulloch, Gabrielle (12 May 2023). "Kindy teachers accept latest pay offer, while primary teachers hold out for more". Stuff. Archived from the original on 12 May 2023. Retrieved 24 May 2023.-

Data.event_text: 16 May  A fire in Loafers Lodge in Wellington kills five residents.
18 May  The 2023 budget is delivered.

links.text: -Reich, Josh (18 May 2023). "Budget 2023: what you need to know". 1News. Archived from the original on 18 May 2023. Retrieved 18 May 2023.-
-Reich, Josh (18 May 2023). "Budget 2023: what you need to know". 1News. Archived from the original on 18 May 2023. Retrieved 18 May 2023.-

Data.event_text: 22 May  The two main teachers' unions, the PPTA and NZEI, suspended strike action in response to progress in pay and work negotiations with the Education Ministry and Education Minister Jan Tinetti.

links.text: -Gerritsen, John (22 May 2023). "Teachers strike actions suspended after talks with minister". Radio New Zealand. Archived from the original on 22 May 2023. Retrieved 24 May 2023.-
-Gerritsen, John (22 May 2023). "Teachers strike actions suspended after talks with minister". Radio New Zealand. Archived from the original on 22 May 2023. Retrieved 24 May 2023.-

Data.event_text: 26 May   From that date bank transactions were processed every day, and weekend transactions (e.g. on Saturday and Sunday) would no longer held until the next "working day" i.e.. Monday.
26 May  Several school climate strike protests are held across New Zealand.

links.text: -"In photos: Hundreds of climate advocates march to parliament". Radio New Zealand. 26 May 2023. Archived from the original on 2 June 2023. Retrieved 3 June 2023.-
-"In photos: Hundreds of climate advocates march to parliament". Radio New Zealand. 26 May 2023. Archived from the original on 2 June 2023. Retrieved 3 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: 5 June  The 2023 King's Birthday and Coronation Honours are announced.

links.text: -"The King's Birthday and Coronation honours list 2023". Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. 5 June 2023. Archived from the original on 4 June 2023. Retrieved 5 June 2023.-
-"The King's Birthday and Coronation honours list 2023". Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. 5 June 2023. Archived from the original on 4 June 2023. Retrieved 5 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: 7 June  Primary school teachers affiliated with the New Zealand Educational Institute (NZEI) voted to accept the Education Ministry's collective agreement offer, which increases salaries and work leaves.

links.text: -"Primary teachers reach deal with government over pay, conditions". Radio New Zealand. 7 June 2023. Archived from the original on 7 June 2023. Retrieved 7 June 2023.-
-"Primary teachers reach deal with government over pay, conditions". Radio New Zealand. 7 June 2023. Archived from the original on 7 June 2023. Retrieved 7 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: 9 June  Secondary school teachers affiliated with the Post Primary Teachers' Association (PPTA) voted to reject the Education Ministry's collective agreement offer and to resume rolling strikes throughout the month.

links.text: -Lyth, Jaime (9 June 2023). "Teachers' strike: Secondary teachers reject collective agreement offers". 9 June 2023. Archived from the original on 8 June 2023. Retrieved 10 June 2023.-
-Lyth, Jaime (9 June 2023). "Teachers' strike: Secondary teachers reject collective agreement offers". 9 June 2023. Archived from the original on 8 June 2023. Retrieved 10 June 2023.-

-Perry, James (9 June 2023). "Secondary School teachers reject offer, continue rolling strikes for remainder of term". Te Ao Māori News. Māori Television. Archived from the original on 9 June 2023. Retrieved 10 June 2023.-

-Perry, James (9 June 2023). "Secondary School teachers reject offer, continue rolling strikes for remainder of term". Te Ao Māori News. Māori Television. Archived from the original on 9 June 2023. Retrieved 10 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: 14 June  Schools and public transportation in Ōpōtiki are suspended due to disruption caused by a tangihanga (funeral) for slain Mongrel Mob Barbarians president Steven Taiatini.

links.text: -Wilson, Megan (14 June 2023). "Ōpōtiki Mongrel Mob Barbarians death: 50 police officers sent to Ōpōtiki ahead of funeral in Whakatāne". Bay of Plenty Times. The New Zealand Herald. Archived from the original on 15 June 2023. Retrieved 22 December 2024.-

-Wilson, Megan (14 June 2023). "Ōpōtiki Mongrel Mob Barbarians death: 50 police officers sent to Ōpōtiki ahead of funeral in Whakatāne". Bay of Plenty Times. The New Zealand Herald. Archived from the original on 15 June 2023. Retrieved 22 December 2024.-

Data.event_text: 16 June  North Auckland's Pūhoi to Warkworth motorway is officially opened by Prime Minister Chris Hipkins and other officials. The motorway opened to traffic on 19 .

links.text: -"North Auckland's Pūhoi to Warkworth motorway officially opened". 1News. TVNZ. 16 June 2023. Archived from the original on 19 June 2023. Retrieved 19 June 2023.-
-"North Auckland's Pūhoi to Warkworth motorway officially opened". 1News. TVNZ. 16 June 2023. Archived from the original on 19 June 2023. Retrieved 19 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: 21 June  The PPTA suspends strikes action after agreeing to an arbitration process to resolve its pay dispute with the Education Ministry.

links.text: -"PPTA calls off industrial action as it agrees to arbitration". Radio New Zealand. 21 June 2023. Archived from the original on 5 August 2023. Retrieved 5 August 2023.-
-"PPTA calls off industrial action as it agrees to arbitration". Radio New Zealand. 21 June 2023. Archived from the original on 5 August 2023. Retrieved 5 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: John Adams is appointed as the third bishop of Palmerston North by Pope Francis. He is consecrated on 30 September by numerous senior Catholic clergy.

links.text: -"Fr John Adams of Christchurch appointed Catholic Bishop of Palmerston North". New Zealand Catholic Bishops Conference. Retrieved 23 November 2023.-

Data.event_text: A state of emergency is declared in Tairāwhiti due to severe weather.

links.text: -"Declared States of Emergency". www.civildefence.govt.nz. Retrieved 24 April 2024.-

Data.event_text: 29 June  Primary school principals affiliated with the NZEI vote to accept the Education Ministry's pay offer consisting of progressive pay rises over the next two years.

links.text: -"Primary principals give pass mark to 6% pay rise, more increases to come". Radio New Zealand. 29 June 2023. Archived from the original on 5 August 2023. Retrieved 5 August 2023.-
-"Primary principals give pass mark to 6% pay rise, more increases to come". Radio New Zealand. 29 June 2023. Archived from the original on 5 August 2023. Retrieved 5 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Plastic ban for fresh produce. New Zealand bans thin plastic bags for fresh produce from supermarkets, becoming the first country to do so. The ban will also extend to plastic straws and cutlery.

links.text: -"New Zealand bans plastic bags for fresh produce in supermarkets". BBC. 3 July 2023. Archived from the original on 3 July 2023. Retrieved 3 July 2023.-
-"New Zealand bans plastic bags for fresh produce in supermarkets". BBC. 3 July 2023. Archived from the original on 3 July 2023. Retrieved 3 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The fuel tax subsidy introduced in March 2022 is removed.

links.text: -"Petrol stations slammed as Govt fuel subsidy comes to an end". 1 News. Retrieved 4 November 2023.-

Data.event_text: 9 July  Chris Hipkins signs a free trade agreement with the European Union in Brussels.

links.text: -"New Zealand signs free trade deal with European Union after years of negotiations". Radio New Zealand. 10 July 2023. Archived from the original on 14 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-
-"New Zealand signs free trade deal with European Union after years of negotiations". Radio New Zealand. 10 July 2023. Archived from the original on 14 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Waka Kotahi announces a temporary ban on Te Huia entering Auckland after twice running through red signals.

links.text: -"Waka Kotahi temporarily bans Te Huia train from operating in Auckland". Radio New Zealand. 11 July 2023. Archived from the original on 12 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-
-"Waka Kotahi temporarily bans Te Huia train from operating in Auckland". Radio New Zealand. 11 July 2023. Archived from the original on 12 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The University of Otago announces a $1.3 million rebrand, including a new te reo Māori name and tohu (symbol).

links.text: -"Million-dollar rebrand to go ahead for University of Otago". Radio New Zealand. 11 July 2023. Archived from the original on 15 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-
-"Million-dollar rebrand to go ahead for University of Otago". Radio New Zealand. 11 July 2023. Archived from the original on 15 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Three years after the 2019 Whakaari/White Island eruption, the trial over failings of health and safety begin. The legal proceedings are the result of WorkSafe's most extensive and complex investigation to date

links.text: -"Whakaari eruption: Mihi whakatau takes place to open trial into disaster". Radio New Zealand. 10 July 2023. Archived from the original on 18 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-
-"Whakaari eruption: Mihi whakatau takes place to open trial into disaster". Radio New Zealand. 10 July 2023. Archived from the original on 18 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: 13 July  Police announce that there have been 388 ram raid style events resulting in 218 prosecutions in the six months ended May.

links.text: -"More than 380 ram raids with 218 prosecutions in six months ended May". Radio New Zealand. 13 July 2023. Archived from the original on 18 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-
-"More than 380 ram raids with 218 prosecutions in six months ended May". Radio New Zealand. 13 July 2023. Archived from the original on 18 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Two children are found safe after going missing for one night at Mavora Lakes.

links.text: -"Two children found after going missing in Southland at Mavora Lakes". Radio New Zealand. 16 July 2023. Archived from the original on 16 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-
-"Two children found after going missing in Southland at Mavora Lakes". Radio New Zealand. 16 July 2023. Archived from the original on 16 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The United Kingdom officially joins the CPTPP in Auckland.

links.text: -"CPTPP: The UK officially joins at meeting in Auckland". Radio New Zealand. 16 July 2023. Archived from the original on 16 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-
-"CPTPP: The UK officially joins at meeting in Auckland". Radio New Zealand. 16 July 2023. Archived from the original on 16 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: 17 July  Lauren Dickason goes to trial for causing the deaths of her three daughters in 2021.

links.text: -"Lauren Dickason trial: Psych expert reveals killer's last words to daughters". The New Zealand Herald. 4 August 2023. Archived from the original on 4 August 2023. Retrieved 4 August 2023.-
-"Lauren Dickason trial: Psych expert reveals killer's last words to daughters". The New Zealand Herald. 4 August 2023. Archived from the original on 4 August 2023. Retrieved 4 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 20 July  A shooting in Central Auckland leaves three people dead.

links.text: -"Two people killed in Auckland CBD shooting, gunman dead, police confirm". Radio New Zealand. 20 July 2023. Archived from the original on 19 July 2023. Retrieved 19 July 2023.-
-"Two people killed in Auckland CBD shooting, gunman dead, police confirm". Radio New Zealand. 20 July 2023. Archived from the original on 19 July 2023. Retrieved 19 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: 31 July  An arbitration panel recommends that secondary school teachers receive a 14.5% pay rise in an effort to end a pay dispute between the Ministry of Education and the Post Primary Teachers Association.

links.text: -Gerritsen, John (31 July 2023). "Secondary teachers should get 14.5 percent pay rise, arbitration panel recommends". Radio New Zealand. Archived from the original on 5 August 2023. Retrieved 5 August 2023.-

-Gerritsen, John (31 July 2023). "Secondary teachers should get 14.5 percent pay rise, arbitration panel recommends". Radio New Zealand. Archived from the original on 5 August 2023. Retrieved 5 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 3 August  The Hawke's Bay Regional Council, Napier City Council, Hastings District Council, Wairoa District Council and Central Hawke's Bay District accept the Government's NZ$556 Cyclone Gabrielle recovery cost-sharing agreement.

links.text: -Hamilton-Irvine, Gary (3 August 2023). "Cyclone Gabrielle: Buyout details agreed for Category 3 homes in Hawke's Bay". Hawkes Bay Today. NZME. Archived from the original on 5 August 2023. Retrieved 5 August 2023.-

-Hamilton-Irvine, Gary (3 August 2023). "Cyclone Gabrielle: Buyout details agreed for Category 3 homes in Hawke's Bay". Hawkes Bay Today. NZME. Archived from the original on 5 August 2023. Retrieved 5 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 4 August  Results for the 2023 Invercargill City Council by-election are released.

links.text: -"Low by-election campaign launch turnout 'sad indictment'". Otago Daily Times. Allied Press. 3 July 2023. Archived from the original on 16 July 2023. Retrieved 3 July 2023.-
-"Low by-election campaign launch turnout 'sad indictment'". Otago Daily Times. Allied Press. 3 July 2023. Archived from the original on 16 July 2023. Retrieved 3 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: 7 August  Nurses affiliated with the New Zealand Nurses Organisation vote to accept a collective pay offer agreement with Te Whatu Ora (Health New Zealand).

links.text: -"Nurses accept pay offer from Te Whatu Ora, strike won't go ahead". Radio New Zealand. 7 August 2023. Archived from the original on 7 August 2023. Retrieved 11 August 2023.-
-"Nurses accept pay offer from Te Whatu Ora, strike won't go ahead". Radio New Zealand. 7 August 2023. Archived from the original on 7 August 2023. Retrieved 11 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Secondary school teachers affiliated with the Post Primary Teachers' Association (PPTA) vote to accept a 14.5% pay rise agreement with the Ministry of Education.

links.text: -McCulloch, Gabrielle (9 August 2023). "Secondary teachers accept pay agreement, union 'delighted'". Stuff. Archived from the original on 11 August 2023. Retrieved 11 August 2023.-
-McCulloch, Gabrielle (9 August 2023). "Secondary teachers accept pay agreement, union 'delighted'". Stuff. Archived from the original on 11 August 2023. Retrieved 11 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 900 unionised Westpac bank workers affiliated with First Union New Zealand stage a two-hour strike seeking a wage increase.

links.text: -Iasona, Seni (9 August 2023). "900 Westpac bank workers across Aotearoa to walk off job demanding better pay". Newshub. Warner Bros. Discovery New Zealand. Archived from the original on 12 August 2023. Retrieved 11 August 2023.-

-Iasona, Seni (9 August 2023). "900 Westpac bank workers across Aotearoa to walk off job demanding better pay". Newshub. Warner Bros. Discovery New Zealand. Archived from the original on 12 August 2023. Retrieved 11 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 15 August  COVID-19 in New Zealand The last remaining COVID-19 public health requirements—namely the seven-day mandatory isolation period for positive cases, and the wearing of face masks in healthcare settings—are removed at 1201 am.

links.text: -"All COVID-19 requirements removed". New Zealand Government. 14 August 2023. Archived from the original on 2 September 2023. Retrieved 14 August 2023.-
-"All COVID-19 requirements removed". New Zealand Government. 14 August 2023. Archived from the original on 2 September 2023. Retrieved 14 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 16 August  Lauren Dickason is found guilty for murdering her three daughters in 2021.

links.text: -"Lauren Dickason murder trial: Mum who killed three daughters found guilty of murder". Newshub. 16 August 2023. Archived from the original on 16 August 2023. Retrieved 16 August 2023.-
-"Lauren Dickason murder trial: Mum who killed three daughters found guilty of murder". Newshub. 16 August 2023. Archived from the original on 16 August 2023. Retrieved 16 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 21 August  Area school teachers accepted a 14.5% pay rise in a pay agreement negotiated by both the PPTA and NZEI.

links.text: -McCulloch, Gabrielle (21 August 2023). "Last major education agreement settled, area school teachers see 14.5% pay jump". Stuff. Archived from the original on 11 September 2023. Retrieved 11 September 2023.-

-McCulloch, Gabrielle (21 August 2023). "Last major education agreement settled, area school teachers see 14.5% pay jump". Stuff. Archived from the original on 11 September 2023. Retrieved 11 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: 5 September  Senior doctors and dentists affiliated Association of Salaried Medical Specialists (ASMS) launched a two-hour strike, rejecting a pay offer from Te Whatu Ora.

links.text: -Maher, Rachel (3 September 2023). "Doctors strike: More than 5000 senior doctors, dentists to strike on Tuesday, more planned". The New Zealand Herald. Archived from the original on 6 September 2023. Retrieved 11 September 2023.-

-Maher, Rachel (3 September 2023). "Doctors strike: More than 5000 senior doctors, dentists to strike on Tuesday, more planned". The New Zealand Herald. Archived from the original on 6 September 2023. Retrieved 11 September 2023.-
-"Hospital doctors and dentists on strike over pay negotiations". Radio New Zealand. 5 September 2023. Archived from the original on 8 September 2023. Retrieved 11 September 2023.-
-"Hospital doctors and dentists on strike over pay negotiations". Radio New Zealand. 5 September 2023. Archived from the original on 8 September 2023. Retrieved 11 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: 8 September  The 53rd New Zealand Parliament is formally dissolved ahead of the 2023 general election.

links.text: -"Dissolution of Parliament". New Zealand Parliament. Archived from the original on 11 September 2023. Retrieved 9 September 2023.-
-"Dissolution of Parliament". New Zealand Parliament. Archived from the original on 11 September 2023. Retrieved 9 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Senior doctors and dentists affiliated with ASMS continue with a second round of strikes in response to a pay dispute with Te Whatu Ora.

links.text: -Martin, Hannah (12 September 2023). "Doctors' strike: 'Woeful' understaffing has life and death consequences' – ED doc". Stuff. Archived from the original on 18 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-

-Martin, Hannah (12 September 2023). "Doctors' strike: 'Woeful' understaffing has life and death consequences' – ED doc". Stuff. Archived from the original on 18 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Corrections officers affiliated with the Corrections Association and Public Service Association (PSA) reject an offer by the Department of Corrections to settle the Prisons' Collective Agreement.

links.text: -Chittock, Niva (13 September 2023). "Department of Corrections staff plan strikes over pay offer". Radio New Zealand. Archived from the original on 20 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-
-Chittock, Niva (13 September 2023). "Department of Corrections staff plan strikes over pay offer". Radio New Zealand. Archived from the original on 20 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: 17 September  Strong wind causes weather warnings and watches are issued throughout country, over 10,000 people lose power. A gust of wind measuring 246 km/h is measured in Cape Turnagain, near the highest ever wind reading in New Zealand at 250 km/h. Over 60 flights are cancelled by Air New Zealand.

links.text: -"Wild weather: Warnings, watches remain in place for wind and rain for much of country". RNZ. 17 September 2023. Archived from the original on 18 September 2023. Retrieved 17 September 2023.-
-"Wild weather: Warnings, watches remain in place for wind and rain for much of country". RNZ. 17 September 2023. Archived from the original on 18 September 2023. Retrieved 17 September 2023.-

-"Thousands without power after 240km/h winds recorded, flights delayed, roofs ripped off, trees down". The New Zealand Herald. 18 September 2023. Archived from the original on 18 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-

-"Thousands without power after 240km/h winds recorded, flights delayed, roofs ripped off, trees down". The New Zealand Herald. 18 September 2023. Archived from the original on 18 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-
-Moore, Rachel (17 September 2023). "Air New Zealand cancels 60 flights due to wild winds". Stuff. Archived from the original on 20 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-
-Moore, Rachel (17 September 2023). "Air New Zealand cancels 60 flights due to wild winds". Stuff. Archived from the original on 20 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: 18 September  The Queenstown Lakes District Council issues a "boil water" notice for Queenstown and Frankton following an outbreak of cryptosporidium.

links.text: -Jack, Amberleigh (18 September 2023). "Queenstown and Frankton residents warned to boil water after eight confirmed sick". Stuff. Archived from the original on 18 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-

-Jack, Amberleigh (18 September 2023). "Queenstown and Frankton residents warned to boil water after eight confirmed sick". Stuff. Archived from the original on 18 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: 19 September  A Westpac helicopter crashes near Mount Pirongia while heading towards a patient.

links.text: -"Rescue chopper crashes into Waikato bush". The New Zealand Herald. 20 September 2023. Archived from the original on 19 September 2023. Retrieved 19 September 2023.-
-"Rescue chopper crashes into Waikato bush". The New Zealand Herald. 20 September 2023. Archived from the original on 19 September 2023. Retrieved 19 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: A 6.0M (initially measured at 6.2M) hits 45 km north of Geraldine at a depth of 10 km.

links.text: -McCulloch, Gabrielle (19 September 2023). "Thousands report feeling strong earthquake in South Island". Stuff. Archived from the original on 19 September 2023. Retrieved 19 September 2023.-
-McCulloch, Gabrielle (19 September 2023). "Thousands report feeling strong earthquake in South Island". Stuff. Archived from the original on 19 September 2023. Retrieved 19 September 2023.-

-"A magnitude 6.0 earthquake occurred 45 km north of Geraldine, New Zealand on Wed Sep 20 2023 9:14 AM. The quake was 11 kilometres deep and the shaking was strong close to the quake". GeoNet. Archived from the original on 19 September 2023. Retrieved 19 September 2023.-

-"A magnitude 6.0 earthquake occurred 45 km north of Geraldine, New Zealand on Wed Sep 20 2023 9:14 AM. The quake was 11 kilometres deep and the shaking was strong close to the quake". GeoNet. Archived from the original on 19 September 2023. Retrieved 19 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Properties are evacuated as a large scrub fire burns in Pukaki Downs, near Twizel.

links.text: -"Houses evacuated as winds fan large blaze near Twizel". RNZ. 20 September 2023. Archived from the original on 23 September 2023. Retrieved 21 September 2023.-
-"Houses evacuated as winds fan large blaze near Twizel". RNZ. 20 September 2023. Archived from the original on 23 September 2023. Retrieved 21 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: 21 September  A state of emergency is declared in the Gore District, following heavy rain and flooding. It is later updated to cover the entire Southland region.

links.text: -"Wild weather: State of emergency declared in Gore with warnings in place for wider South Island". RNZ. 21 September 2023. Archived from the original on 23 September 2023. Retrieved 21 September 2023.-

-"Wild weather: State of emergency declared in Gore with warnings in place for wider South Island". RNZ. 21 September 2023. Archived from the original on 23 September 2023. Retrieved 21 September 2023.-
-"Emergency declared in Southland". RNZ. 21 September 2023. Archived from the original on 21 September 2023. Retrieved 22 September 2023.-
-"Emergency declared in Southland". RNZ. 21 September 2023. Archived from the original on 21 September 2023. Retrieved 22 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: 26 September  Multiple ferry sailings in the Cook Strait are cancelled due to high winds.

links.text: -"Cook Strait ferry cancellations amid wild winds". 1 News. Retrieved 26 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: 1 October  Driving test resit fees are removed by Waka Kotahi.

links.text: -"Big changes on the way for driver licence fees". 1 News. Retrieved 6 January 2024.-

Data.event_text: 3 November  The Electoral Commission concludes vote counting, which shows that the leading National Party requires support from both ACT and New Zealand First parties to form a government after the final tally reveals a shift in parliamentary seats.

links.text: -"New Zealand's final election count means incoming premier Christopher Luxon needs broader support". AP News. 3 November 2023. Retrieved 4 November 2023.-

Data.event_text: 4 November  Miramar Peninsula is declared pest free.

links.text: -"Miramar Peninsula residents celebrate elimination of pests". 1 News. Retrieved 6 November 2023.-

Data.event_text: 8 November  Over 100 early childhood education centres strike for the first time.

links.text: -"Kindergarten strike: Early childhood education centres across New Zealand will close on Wednesday". The New Zealand Herald. 6 November 2023. Retrieved 6 November 2023.-

Data.event_text: 10 November  China Southern Airlines starts its seasonal route between Christchurch and Guangzhou.[citation needed]
13 November  Interislander ferry Kaiarahi has a hole ripped out of its hull as it comes into berth. It will be out of service for about a week.

links.text: -"Cook Strait ferry has 'dramatic' hole in hull". RNZ. 13 November 2023. Retrieved 8 August 2024.-

Data.event_text: 21 November  The water treatment plant of Te Aroha temporarily shuts down due to bad weather.

links.text: -"Residents in Te Aroha, Waikato, asked to 'urgently' save water after town's treatment plant forced to shut down". Newshub. Archived from the original on 21 November 2023. Retrieved 21 November 2023.-

-"Residents in Te Aroha, Waikato, asked to 'urgently' save water after town's treatment plant forced to shut down". Newshub. Archived from the original on 21 November 2023. Retrieved 21 November 2023.-

Data.event_text: Prime Minister-designate Christopher Luxon announces coalition arrangements and deals have finished with ACT and New Zealand First.

links.text: -"Live: Coalition talks conclude, signing ceremony due on Friday". Stuff. 23 November 2023. Retrieved 23 November 2023.-

Data.event_text: 16 institutions nationwide including St Kentigern College, Wellington Hospital, Bowen Hospital, Auckland City Hospital and Manukau Superclinic receive email bomb threats, prompting lockdowns and police searches.

links.text: -"No danger from threatening emails sent to schools, hospitals – police". 1News. TVNZ. 23 November 2023. Archived from the original on 23 November 2023. Retrieved 23 November 2023.-
-"No danger from threatening emails sent to schools, hospitals – police". 1News. TVNZ. 23 November 2023. Archived from the original on 23 November 2023. Retrieved 23 November 2023.-

Data.event_text: Pro-Palestinian protesters blockade the entry to the Ports of Auckland in response to the 2023 Israel-Hamas war. Police arrested at least six protesters.

links.text: -"Israel-Hamas war: Police arrest six after clash with pro-Palestine protesters blocking entrance to Port of Auckland". The New Zealand Herald. 23 November 2023. Retrieved 23 November 2023.-

Data.event_text: A formal signing ceremony and announcement of ministerial roles for the Sixth National Government takes place.
Several North Auckland schools including Orewa College receive email bomb threats, which are linked to the threats yesterday.

links.text: -"'Bomb threat' closes schools as more concerning emails received". 1News. TVNZ. 24 November 2023. Retrieved 23 November 2023.-

Data.event_text: 25 November  The Port Waikato by-election takes place.

links.text: -"Port Waikato electorate by-election date announced". RNZ News. 10 October 2023. Retrieved 10 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: 27 November  The Sixth National Government is sworn in by the Governor-General, Dame Cindy Kiro at Government House.
The official cash rate is kept at 5.5%.

links.text: -"Official cash rate remains at 5.5%". 1 News. Retrieved 1 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Prime Minister Luxon unveils his "100-day plan", with 49 policy changes.

links.text: -"Prime Minister Luxon reveals his '49 actions' for first 100 days". 1 News. Retrieved 1 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: 1 December  The Government begins a reserve against proposed amendments to World Health Organisation health regulations to consider these against a 'National Interest Test'.

links.text: -"Coalition's WHO policy leaves public health expert 'baffled'". RNZ. 1 December 2023. Retrieved 1 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: 3 December  New Zealand signs the "COP28 UAE declaration on sustainable agriculture, resilient food systems and climate action".

links.text: -"NZ signs COP28 declaration on sustainable agriculture, food production". 1 News. Retrieved 3 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Te Pāti Māori (Māori Party) organises a series of nationwide protests known as the National Māori Action Day to protest against the Sixth National Government's policies on co-governance and the Treaty of Waitangi. The protests coincided with the first meeting of the 54th New Zealand Parliament.

links.text: -"National Māori Action Day – Te Pāti Māori protests in pictures". Radio New Zealand. 5 December 2023. Retrieved 5 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: The 54th New Zealand Parliament begins, following the Commission Opening of Parliament where MPs were sworn in and Gerry Brownlee was elected as Speaker of the House.

links.text: -"Watch LIVE – MPs sworn-in at Parliament opening, eyes on Te Pāti Māori". Newshub. Archived from the original on 7 December 2023. Retrieved 7 December 2023.-
-"Watch LIVE – MPs sworn-in at Parliament opening, eyes on Te Pāti Māori". Newshub. Archived from the original on 7 December 2023. Retrieved 7 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Hundreds of Palestinian solidarity protesters gather at the New Zealand Parliament calling for a ceasefire in the 2023 Israel-Hamas War.

links.text: -"Hundreds of protesters at Parliament to call for ceasefire in Gaza". Radio New Zealand. 5 December 2023. Retrieved 5 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: 6 December  The State Opening of Parliament takes place.

links.text: -"Governor-General Dame Cindy Kiro highlights government's 'extensive, ambitious' agenda at State Opening of Parliament". RNZ News. 6 December 2023. Retrieved 6 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: 8 December  Queenstown lifts its water boil notice after two months.

links.text: -"Queenstown boil water notice lifted after more than two months". 1 News. Retrieved 8 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: 10 December  United Airlines starts its seasonal route between Christchurch and San Francisco. It marks the first time an American airline has flown non-stop between the South Island and the United States.

links.text: -"US airline's first direct flight service to South Island lands in Christchurch". RNZ. 10 December 2023. Retrieved 12 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: A protest is held at Te Papa. The English translation on a wooden display of the Te Tiriti o Waitangi at Te Papa is defaced with spray paint.

links.text: -"Te Papa protest: English Te Tiriti display panel vandalised". 1 News. Retrieved 11 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Bishop Michael Gielen reconsiders the future for a catholic cathedral for the Catholic Diocese of Christchurch, following the 2010 Canterbury earthquake.

links.text: -"Catholic bishop considers ditching central city site for new cathedral". The Press. Retrieved 12 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: 12 December  Severe hailstorms, lightning, thunderstorms and a tornado hit the Canterbury Plains and Wellington regions, leading to flooding and power outages for thousands of customers.

links.text: -"In pictures: Wild weather wreaks havoc across Wellington Region". RNZ. 12 December 2023. Retrieved 12 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Criminal Cases Review Commission sends Mikaere Oketopa's case back to the Court of Appeal of New Zealand for it to be reconsidered over "strong concerns with the police investigation, and his convictions". Oketopa has a conviction for the 1994 rape and murder of Anne-Maree Ellens in Christchurch.

links.text: -White, Mike (15 December 2023). "'I wasn't there': Mikaere Oketopa the victim of a miscarriage of justice, investigating body finds". The Press. Retrieved 15 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Winston Peters has an engagement with Fiji's Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka, who each exchange gifts. This marks Peters' first overseas engagement as foreign minister.

links.text: -"Winston Peters swaps gifts with Fiji's PM on first overseas engagement". 1 News. Retrieved 15 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Judith Collins is appointed as King's Counsel.

links.text: -"Judith Collins appointed as King's Counsel". 1 News. Retrieved 15 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: 16 December  Cathay Pacific starts its seasonal route between Christchurch and Hong Kong.

links.text: -"Direct Christchurch to Hong Kong flights resume". www.christchurchairport.co.nz. Retrieved 21 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: 17 December  Let's Get Wellington Moving, a plan to improve Wellington's public transport, is cancelled by the new government.

links.text: -"Major Wellington infrastructure project scrapped". 1 News. Retrieved 17 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: The government announces new rules for primary and intermediate schools. Starting in Term 1 2024, students will be taught one hour of reading, writing and maths for each subject per day. Starting in Term 2, cellphones will be banned during school for the students.

links.text: -"Govt introduces new rules for reading, writing, maths and phones". 1 News. Retrieved 20 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Finance Minister Nicola Willis releases the 2023 mini-budget.

links.text: -"Willis unveils $7.4 billion in cuts as gloomy economy weighs on Government". The New Zealand Herald. 22 December 2023. Retrieved 21 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: 30 December  The 2024 New Year Honours are announced.

links.text: -"New Year honours list 2023". Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. 30 December 2023. Retrieved 30 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: 31 December  The Clean Car Discount scheme ends.

links.text: -Green, Kate (31 December 2023). "Clean Car Discount scheme ends today removing rebates, 'ute-tax'". RNZ News. Archived from the original on 31 December 2023. Retrieved 3 January 2024.-
-Green, Kate (31 December 2023). "Clean Car Discount scheme ends today removing rebates, 'ute-tax'". RNZ News. Archived from the original on 31 December 2023. Retrieved 3 January 2024.-
